title: 104_hr4162
content: The Act titled "Continued Participation Pension Act of 1996" allows certain individuals to continue participating in defined benefit plans under the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974. The Continued Participation Pension Act of 1996 allows qualified beneficiaries to continue accruing benefits in a defined benefit plan after a qualifying event. Qualified beneficiaries can elect continued participation within a specified period, ensuring they do not lose eligibility to accrue benefits. The Continued Participation Pension Act of 1996 allows qualified beneficiaries to continue accruing benefits in a defined benefit plan after a qualifying event. The period of continued participation is considered service with the employer, and earnings and forfeitures are not included in determining liabilities. In a multiemployer plan, the allocation of liabilities is determined by the plan sponsor or the last employer before the qualifying event. The Continued Participation Pension Act of 1996 allows qualified beneficiaries to continue accruing benefits in a defined benefit plan after a qualifying event. The period of participation extends from the qualifying event date to the earliest of reaching normal retirement age, employer ceasing to provide the plan, or benefits ceasing due to failure to make timely contributions. The Continued Participation Pension Act of 1996 allows qualified beneficiaries to continue accruing benefits in a defined benefit plan after a qualifying event. Qualified beneficiaries electing continued participation are liable for funding plan obligations for benefits. The plan allocates applicable contributions to qualified beneficiaries in the same manner as other beneficiaries. The Continued Participation Pension Act of 1996 allows qualified beneficiaries to continue accruing benefits in a defined benefit plan after a qualifying event. The plan shall provide benefit accruals for voluntary employee contributions only if available prior to the event. Contributions by the qualified beneficiary during continued participation should not exceed 102 percent of the applicable contribution for the period. The Continued Participation Pension Act of 1996 allows qualified beneficiaries to continue accruing benefits in a defined benefit plan after a qualifying event. Contributions may be made in monthly installments and must not be required before 45 days after the initial election. The election period begins before benefits accrual would cease and lasts at least 90 days. The Continued Participation Pension Act of 1996 allows qualified beneficiaries to continue accruing benefits in a defined benefit plan after a qualifying event. An election of continued participation by a qualified beneficiary includes other beneficiaries who would cease to be beneficiaries due to the qualifying event. There is an exception for defined benefit plans with fewer than 20 employees. The applicable contribution for continued participation is based on the actuarial value of benefit accruals. The Continued Participation Pension Act of 1996 allows qualified beneficiaries to continue accruing benefits in a defined benefit plan after a qualifying event, which includes termination or reduction of employment. The Continued Participation Pension Act of 1996 allows qualified beneficiaries to continue accruing benefits in a defined benefit plan after a qualifying event, such as termination or reduction of employment, or the death of the participant. The Continued Participation Pension Act of 1996 applies to plan years starting on or after July 1, 1996. For defined benefit plans under collective bargaining agreements ratified before the Act's enactment, the effective date is the later of the agreement's termination or January 1, 2000.
